children.value: This page will show you how to set up and run a local test network, deploy the
smart contracts to that local test network, and then connect to that local test network with colonyJS.
For this example, you will need the following tools:
If you have these installed, feel free to skip ahead to the next section.
or higher. If you do not have Git installed, check out
or higher. If you do not have Node installed, check out
and some of our tools require that you have Yarn installed. You are more than welcome to try running commands with
but we recommend using Yarn version
or higher. If you do not have Yarn installed, check out
You will also need to have
smart contracts use a Docker image for the solidity compiler. We recommend using Docker Community Edition
or higher, which starts at version
. If you do not have Docker installed, check out
Are you building a project from scratch or integrating colonyJS into an existing project? If the latter and you have both Git and Yarn already initialized, you can skip ahead to the next section.
Within the root directory, run the following command:
This will initialize your project as a Git repository. Now would be a good time to add a
and any other files you want Git to ignore.
Within the root directory, run the following command and follow the prompt:
This will initialize your project as a Node package, allowing you to install other packages.
In order for colonyJS to interact with

in a local development environment, you will need to compile the colonyNetwork smart contracts, deploy the contracts to a local test network, and then make the contract data available within your project.

Do not fear! We created a simple command line tool to make this easier for you. No need to install and configure services and add the colonyNetwork repository as a submodule to start building with colonyJS. We bundled up everything for you in
is a command line tool that pulls down and installs
behind the scenes and makes services within colonyNetwork available via
commands. Everything you need to run a local test network, compile and deploy the colonyNetwork smart contracts, and serve the contract data are made accessible in
Note: You can specify different colonyNetwork versions with the
option added to any of the
commands. The default version is using the
is not recommended if you are using colonyJS because colonyJS will not yet have an official release that supports an unreleased version of the colonyNetwork smart contracts.
Next, you will need to install the following packages:
You can install these packages using the following command:
